perturbation.original_text:
Software license fees associated with Software license agreements in which the sales cycle begins on or after May 1, 1994 (hereinafter "New Software license agreements") for Product sites located in the Territory, shall be allocated and distributed as follows:

Gross Software Revenue Generated % to Distributor
-------------------------------- ----------------
Per Annum July 1- June 30 US$O -- $999,999 40%
US$1,O00,000 + 50%
perturbation.changed_text: Software license fees associated with Software license agreements in which the sales cycle begins on or after May 1, 1994 (hereinafter "New Software license agreements") for Product sites located in the Territory, shall be allocated and distributed as mutually agreed upon in writing by both parties.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific royalty percentages based on gross software revenue, the contract introduces uncertainty. Later, section 2.3 mentions 'License Renewal and Maintenance Fees will be split evenIy with 50% distributed to Developer and 50% distributed to Distributor, also subject to paragraph 4 of this section 2.3.' Paragraph 4 speaks about royalties to entities outside the territory affecting allocation to Distributor. If royalties are not clearly defined based on revenue, it creates uncertainty in enforcing the split.

perturbation.original_text: Developer occasionally uses third party trademarks, trade names or screen shots in advertising; Distributor may not use such trademarks, trade names or screen shots in writing for advertising without the prior written permission from the third party developer.
perturbation.changed_text: Developer occasionally uses third party trademarks, trade names or screen shots in advertising; Distributor may use such trademarks, trade names or screen shots in writing for advertising.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the prior written permission needed from the third party developer for the use of trademarks, trade names or screenshots in writing for advertising, this creates a conflict with section 9.1, Copyright Indemnification, which indemnifies distributor from any copyright claims, but the removal of this clause creates an exception that may void the protection if the distributor uses a third party's trademark/screenshot without permission.

perturbation.original_text: For End-Users that have a World Wide Retainer in place, Distributor will provide local support in the Territory as defined in the World Wide Retainer (Schedule F).
perturbation.changed_text: For End-Users that have a World Wide Retainer in place, Distributor will provide local support in the Territory.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the reference to Schedule F, which defines the terms of the World Wide Retainer, there's now ambiguity regarding the specific support obligations. This creates a conflict because, without Schedule F, the precise services, response times, and other conditions are undefined, making it difficult to determine if Distributor is fulfilling its support obligations as stated in the agreement.
